message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Vote: constitutive character → shortened to character">
The author proposes: introduce "constitutive character (德 De)" at first occurrence with a TN that explicitly tells the reader it will be shortened to "character" in the following paragraphs. Then use plain "character" throughout the rest of the text.

This gives:
- Precision at introduction (constitutive character)
- Lightweight running text (character)
- Reader is explicitly told about the shortening, so no confusion

YES or NO? Brief response.
</teammate-message>

input.content: **YES.** This is the right solution. The TN at introduction does the philosophical work; "character" carries the text without drag. Clean and practical.
input.summary: YES — constitutive character intro, then plain character

routing.summary: YES — constitutive character intro, then plain character
routing.content: **YES.** This is the right solution. The TN at introduction does the philosophical work; "character" carries the text without drag. Clean and practical.

content.text: Vote confirmed: **YES**. The approach is elegant -- "constitutive character (德, *De*)" at introduction with a TN explaining the shortening, then plain "character" in running text. Precision where it matters, lightness everywhere else.
